currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid.

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. In addition to money, players are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. If they want to go pro, they can leave the college and join a team.

If they want to go pro, they can leave the college and join a team. If they want an education, they attend college.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. If they want to go pro, they can leave the college and join a team. If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus oIf they want both, they can find the suitable balance.

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.

currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.

  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, College athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on sare offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is t
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, before you begin life 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, before you begin the cas an adult
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, before you begin the commitments and woas an adult
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a adult

McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to newbefore you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultanel

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays, so wh

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays, so why should we

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays, so why should we singl

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays so why should we single out athlete

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college so why should we single out athletes?

Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.

currentDoc:
Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.
 

We should leave colleg

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.
 

We should leave colleges as a sacred

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.
 

We should leave colleges as a sacred

But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.
 

We should leave colleges as a sacred institution

  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.
 

We should leave colleges as a sacred institution of learning...

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

Should College Athletes Be Paid?

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects.

Do you think college athletes should be paid? Or is a college scholarship and other non-monetary perks like the opportunity to play in front of cheering fans enough?

In “Paying Students to Play Would Ruin College Sports," Cody J. McDavis writes: “Paying student-athletes might sound like a fairer way to treat students who generate so much money and attention for their colleges (not to mention the television networks that broadcast their games). But paying athletes would distort the economics of college sports in a way that would hurt the broader community of student-athletes, universities, fans and alumni. A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.
 

We should leave colleges as a sacred institution of learning...and let the unequal bartering

A handful of big sports programs would pay top dollar for a select few athletes, while almost every other college would get caught up in a bidding war it couldn't afford."

Do you find his argument persuasive? What possible difficulties or downsides might there be in providing monetary compensation to players?

---

In my opinion, college athletes should not be paid. To do so would serve to commercialize college sports and the value of a college education. Players on scholarship are offered free room and board, so a scholarship is essentially payment for their physical and mental commitment to the team and school. 

If they want an education, they attend college. If they want to focus on sports full time, they can go pro. If they want both, they can find the suitable balance. 

 believe the essential point is that college is not a job.
  The goal of education is to offer an environment where students are exposed to and encouraged to pursue interests and viewpoints that aren’t necessarily personally beneficial. College is the fine-tuning of your skills, the exposure to new ideas, before you begin the commitments and worries of life as a complete adult. 
By paying athletes, the college experience would be cheapened.
  The value of a degree would drop, as graduates would essentially be viewed as professionals fulfilling their contractual obligation to the university (paying tuition and sitting through lectures). 

The rest of the student body, the non-athletes, while still receiving scholarship money, would be expected to earn an actual living in the ‘real world'.  This would be troublesome from many aspects. 

hose who don’t have a chance to play professionally are essentially cheated of this opportunity. to both "earn and learn" simultaneously. 
No other career path pays for attending college, so why should we single out athletes? hose students who do not have the athleticism to be a college athlete are punished for what they cannot do.
 

We should leave colleges as a sacred institution of learning...and let the unequal bartering of
